greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: When adding some positive divisors of n in order from lowest divisor to highest divisor, a(n) is lowest sum achievable which is >= n.
comment: Often, but not always, a(n)=n+A054024(n). The exceptions to this rule are at n=24, 36, 48, 60, 72, 84,90, 96, 108, ... - _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 14 2007
link: Harvey P. Dale, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: 12's divisors are 1,2,3,4,6 and 12. Adding the divisors in order we have:
Of these sums, 1+2+3+4+6 = 16 is the lowest which is >= 12. So a(12) = 16.
maple: A117553 := proc(n) local divs,a,i ; divs := numtheory[divisors](n) ; a := op(1,divs) ; i := 1 ; while a < n do i := i+1 ; a := a+op(i,divs) ; od ; RETURN(a) ; end: for n from 1 to 80 do printf("%d, ",A117553(n)) ; od ; # _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 14 2007
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Mar 28 2006
ext: More terms from _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 14 2007
